20101221131758.000|20101221131800.000|TR0|$6.2 billion, but there is still a lot of 
20101221131800.000|20101221131802.000|TR0|concerns over how you're going to pay for 
20101221131802.000|20101221131804.000|TR0|this.  So, how would you pay for it?
20101221131804.000|20101221131806.000|TR0|
20101221131806.000|20101221131809.000|TR0|KIRSTEN:  Well, we've come up with some 
20101221131809.000|20101221131811.000|TR0|solutions.  The initial pay for it (ph) 
20101221131811.000|20101221131813.000|TR0|that was passed in the House, many of the 
20101221131813.000|20101221131815.000|TR0|Senate Republicans did not like, so we 
20101221131815.000|20101221131817.000|TR0|decided to change it.  Right now, it's a 
20101221131817.000|20101221131820.000|TR0|fee.  When the U.S. government has a 
20101221131820.000|20101221131822.000|TR0|procurement contract with a foreign 
20101221131822.000|20101221131824.000|TR0|company, we're putting a 2 percent on that 
20101221131824.000|20101221131826.000|TR0|company if their company won't sign the 
20101221131826.000|20101221131828.000|TR0|procurement agreements.  Meaning, they 
20101221131828.000|20101221131831.000|TR0|won't let us trade with their companies 
20101221131831.000|20101221131833.000|TR0|under favorable terms.
20101221131833.000|20101221131835.000|TR0|
20101221131835.000|20101221131837.000|TR0|And so, that's a fee there.  And then, 
20101221131837.000|20101221131839.000|TR0|there's a fee on visas for H1B and L1 
20101221131839.000|20101221131842.000|TR0|visas of foreign workers that come into 
20101221131842.000|20101221131844.000|TR0|this country for companies that employ 
20101221131844.000|20101221131846.000|TR0|more than 50 percent of foreign workers.  
20101221131846.000|20101221131848.000|TR0|So, these are companies that really aren't 
20101221131848.000|20101221131850.000|TR0|helping to create jobs here in America for 
20101221131850.000|20101221131853.000|TR0|Americans.
20101221131853.000|20101221131855.000|TR0|
20101221131855.000|20101221131857.000|TR0|ROBERTS:  So, that brings you up to about, 
20101221131857.000|20101221131859.000|TR0|if I got the figures correctly, $4.5 
20101221131859.000|20101221131901.000|TR0|billion.  So, where does the other money 
20101221131901.000|20101221131904.000|TR0|come from?
20101221131904.000|20101221131906.000|TR0|
20101221131906.000|20101221131908.000|TR0|GILLIBRAND:  The last fee is on foreigners 
20101221131908.000|20101221131910.000|TR0|that come to visit this country.  There's 
20101221131910.000|20101221131912.000|TR0|a fee in place that overwhelmingly 
20101221131912.000|20101221131915.000|TR0|supported the Senate.  We're just 
20101221131915.000|20101221131917.000|TR0|continuing that fee to 2021.  And that 
20101221131917.000|20101221131919.000|TR0|gets us to our 6.2.
20101221131919.000|20101221131921.000|TR0|
20101221131921.000|20101221131923.000|TR0|ROBERTS:  Now, you got three senators on

20101221131943.000|20101221131945.000|TR0|GILLIBRAND:  Well, this is a House bill, 
20101221131945.000|20101221131948.000|TR0|and this bill has been through 21 hearings 
20101221131948.000|20101221131950.000|TR0|in the House, all of the committees of 
20101221131950.000|20101221131952.000|TR0|jurisdiction in the house, many Republican 
20101221131952.000|20101221131954.000|TR0|amendments added and passed overwhelmingly 
20101221131954.000|20101221131956.000|TR0|in the house with 17 Republican votes.  
20101221131956.000|20101221131959.000|TR0|So, we brought this bill over to the 
20101221131959.000|20101221132001.000|TR0|Senate.  I introduced this bill last year, 
20101221132001.000|20101221132003.000|TR0|and since that time, we had a hearing in 
20101221132003.000|20101221132005.000|TR0|the Senate, in the health committee where

20101221132029.000|20101221132032.000|TR0|ROBERTS:  Yes.  There's one other

20101221132034.000|20101221132036.000|TR0|Gillibrand, and that is that this 
20101221132036.000|20101221132038.000|TR0|represents a fairly substantial new

20101221132047.000|20101221132049.000|TR0|fact, it is a capped fund.  We know

20101221132058.000|20101221132100.000|TR0|families that live right at ground zero 
20101221132100.000|20101221132102.000|TR0|are known.  And so, it's capped fund.

20101221132109.000|20101221132111.000|TR0|are eligible.  There's 22 diseases that

20101221132855.000|20101221132858.000|TR0|question is, how do you harness the energy

20101221133854.000|20101221133856.000|TR0|should care about what happens today."  
20101221133856.000|20101221133858.000|TR0|And Poppy Harlow joins us with a "A.M." 
20101221133858.000|20101221133900.000|TR0|original, and a story you'll only see on 
20101221133900.000|20101221133902.000|TR0|"AMERICAN MORNING." Trying to break down, 
20101221133902.000|20101221133905.000|TR0|first of all, why this is so divisive, and

20101221133907.000|20101221133909.000|TR0|
20101221133909.000|20101221133911.000|TR0|POPPY HARLOW, CNNMONEY.COM:  It's very

20101221133916.000|20101221133918.000|TR0|here.  We're talking about net neutrality. 
20101221133918.000|20101221133920.000|TR0| You probably haven't heard of it, but for

20101221134402.000|20101221134404.000|TR0|about our drinking water.  An analysis of 
20101221134404.000|20101221134406.000|TR0|tap water in 35 cities found high levels

20101221134607.000|20101221134609.000|TR0|of the matter is when you find it in 31 
20101221134609.000|20101221134611.000|TR0|out of 35 cities, that tells you that you 
20101221134611.000|20101221134613.000|TR0|ought to be looking more carefully.        
20101221134613.000|20101221134616.000|TR0|     This chemical is widely used in 
20101221134616.000|20101221134618.000|TR0|industry.  It's used for metal plating.

20101221134620.000|20101221134622.000|TR0|processes. Some of it occurs naturally, 
20101221134622.000|20101221134624.000|TR0|but that's not believed to be the main 
20101221134624.000|20101221134627.000|TR0|source of these contamination problems.
20101221134627.000|20101221134629.000|TR0|
20101221134629.000|20101221134631.000|TR0|And to be honest, I think what we're 
20101221134631.000|20101221134633.000|TR0|looking at here is not a reason for panic. 
20101221134633.000|20101221134635.000|TR0| This is a long-term exposure concern, low 
20101221134635.000|20101221134638.000|TR0|levels. The health risk is cancer.  That 
20101221134638.000|20101221134640.000|TR0|takes a long time to develop.  So this is 
20101221134640.000|20101221134642.000|TR0|an early indication, I think, of the need 
20101221134642.000|20101221134644.000|TR0|for the government to take a closer look.
20101221134644.000|20101221134646.000|TR0|
20101221134646.000|20101221134649.000|TR0|And then need to do a couple of things.  
20101221134649.000|20101221134651.000|TR0|One, we need to do more testing.  Right

20101221134704.000|20101221134706.000|TR0|risk is cancer.  That takes a long time to 
20101221134706.000|20101221134708.000|TR0|develop.  So this is an early indication, 
20101221134708.000|20101221134711.000|TR0|I think, of the need for the government to

20101221134717.000|20101221134719.000|TR0|One, we need to do more testing.  Right 
20101221134719.000|20101221134722.000|TR0|now, no water utilities outside of 
20101221134722.000|20101221134724.000|TR0|California are required to test for this 
20101221134724.000|20101221134726.000|TR0|chemical.  Two, we need to try and 
20101221134726.000|20101221134728.000|TR0|identify where we find it in water,

20101221134730.000|20101221134733.000|TR0|contamination problem that we could clean 
20101221134733.000|20101221134735.000|TR0|up.  And then, three, we need the 
20101221134735.000|20101221134737.000|TR0|government to set a standard so that 
20101221134737.000|20101221134739.000|TR0|utilities will know just how much they 
20101221134739.000|20101221134741.000|TR0|need to do in order to clean it up.
20101221134741.000|20101221134744.000|TR0|
20101221134744.000|20101221134746.000|TR0|KIRAN CHETRY, CNN ANCHOR:  Right.  Because 
20101221134746.000|20101221134748.000|TR0|you're saying I mean, at this point the

20101221134806.000|20101221134808.000|TR0|Brita filter that doesn't get this out,

20101221134814.000|20101221134817.000|TR0|tough contaminant to scrub out of drinking

20101221134819.000|20101221134821.000|TR0|system in the home.  Most people I think 
20101221134821.000|20101221134823.000|TR0|can't afford it and to be honest we have

20101221134825.000|20101221134828.000|TR0|contaminated to the point where we're

20101221134830.000|20101221134832.000|TR0|
20101221134832.000|20101221134834.000|TR0|This might be one of those instances where 
20101221134834.000|20101221134836.000|TR0|in order to deal with a carcinogen in tap 
20101221134836.000|20101221134839.000|TR0|water we're going to have to spend some 
20101221134839.000|20101221134841.000|TR0|money.  We should have prevented the 
20101221134841.000|20101221134843.000|TR0|pollution to begin with.
20101221134843.000|20101221134845.000|TR0|
20101221134845.000|20101221134847.000|TR0|JOHN ROBERTS, CNN ANCHOR:  And let's -- 
20101221134847.000|20101221134850.000|TR0|let's just come back to this idea of 
20101221134850.000|20101221134852.000|TR0|regulation.  The EPA does have recommended 
20101221134852.000|20101221134854.000|TR0|safe levels for total chromium but that 
20101221134854.000|20101221134856.000|TR0|includes --      (CROSSTALK)
20101221134856.000|20101221134858.000|TR0|
20101221134858.000|20101221134901.000|TR0|COOK:  Correct.
